qas.question: Who ordered research on the Herald?

answers.text: Cecil King from Mark Abrams of Sussex University

qas.question: What was named as a potential reason for the Herald's decline?
What type of people was the new paper supposed to attract?
What was the advertising budget of the new paper?
What was the number of papers in the first print run of the Times?

context: Research commissioned by <a0_0>Cecil King from Mark Abrams of Sussex University<a0_0/>, The Newspaper Reading Public of Tomorrow, identified <a1_0>demographic changes<a1_0/> which suggested reasons why the Herald might be in decline. The new paper was intended to add a readership of <a2_0>'social radicals'<a2_0/> to the Herald's 'political radicals'. Launched with an advertising budget of <a3_0>£400,000<a3_0/> the brash new paper "burst forth with tremendous energy", according to The Times. Its initial print run of <a4_0>3.5 million<a4_0/> was attributed to 'curiosity' and the 'advantage of novelty', and had declined to the previous circulation of the Daily Herald (1.2 million) within a few weeks.
